awd_titl_txt: Developing a Computational Physics Lab Integrated with Upper-division Physics Content
awd_abstract_narration:
An upper-division computational physics course is being developed which runs parallel to and in synchrony with the existing junior-year physics courses that are being developed within the "Paradigms in Physics" project at Oregon State University (OSU). 
 
Computation in physics courses is commonly treated in one of two ways. Either students run existing simulations in order to aid their understanding of physics, or physics examples are introduced ad hoc as applications of the numerical methods that students are learning to use in performing their own computations.  While both of these approaches have value, this project serves to create a course that teaches students physics by having them create their own computations within the context of upper division courses. To this end, a project-driven laboratory experience in computational physics (utilizing course-integrated Python oriented modules) is introduced at an advanced level.  In this laboratory course, students are learning to use important computational tools in the same manner as a professional physicist.  In view of the importance of computation to the professional scientist, the course seeks to teach at a level that is accessible to all physics majors, with particular care taken for those who are least comfortable using computers.

This project is producing a set of six computational laboratory modules (with corresponding curricular materials) that are being evaluated and made available for use at other colleges and universities. Although the content is tailored and organized to fit the junior-year curriculum at OSU, the materials are designed to be sufficiently modular so as to be readily incorporated into the upper-division physics curriculum at other colleges and universities. Workshops are being developed for AAPT national meetings that will directly increase the visibility of these computational modules for other users.

por.por_cntn:
David Roundy developed upper-division computational physics course
that runs parallel to and in synchrony with the existing junior-year
physics courses that were developed through the Paradigms in Physics
project at Oregon State University.  The new course is a one-credit
year-long laboratory which addresses challenges in student
understanding that have been observed through the Paradigms project.

Computation in physics courses is commonly treated in one of two ways.
Either students simply run existing simulations in order to aid their
understanding of physics, or physics examples are introduced ad hoc as
applications of the numerical methods that students are learning to
use to perform their own computations.  While both of these approaches
have value, this project aimed to create a course that teaches
students physics by having them create their own computations.

To this end, Roundy introduced a project-driven laboratory experience
in computational physics at an advanced level.  In this laboratory
course, students learn to use the computational tools that are used by
professional physicists, in the way that a professional physicist
does.  Students apply numerical techniques using computer calculations
to solve physical problems that are less amenable to analytic
solutions.  This includes practice in computer programming, which has
become an essential tool for all physicists, experimental, theoretical
and computational.  In view of this, the course is taught at a level
that is accessible to all physics majors, with particular care taken
for those who are least comfortable using computers.  In the final
term taught under this grant, a majority of Oregon State University
physics majors took the computational lab course.

The new computational lab coordinates with the existing upper-division
curriculum, and to reinforce the learning of physics concepts.  This
has been accomplished by addressing perceived student learning
difficulties as well as exploring additional topics that were not
covered in existing courses due to time constraints.  Although
students are taught numerical methods, the course is centered on and
organized around topics in physics, and the learning of physics is a
primary goal alongside the goal of learning to use computers
effectively.

The greatest impact of this work is the application and testing of
pair programming pedagogy in a computational physics context.  Pair
programming has been demonstrated to both be effective and to level
gender differences when used in computer science courses.  However,
the benefits of this approach in a computational physics course, with
many students having very little programming experience, was far
greater than was anticipated.  Roundy have introduced this pedagogy to
other physicists through talks at four disciplinary conferences, and
intends to continue championing this approach, which
disproportionately benefits students with less experience and
confidence in computer programming.  In other words, those need the
most help get the most help from this teaching approach, while the
project-based approach allows advanced students to creatively
experiment with the physical systems after they have completed the
basic tasks.

 


Last Modified: 06/24/2015
Modified by: David J Roundy

Images (1 of )
